title: 1 Kings Chapter 14 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Kings chapter 14 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Kings Chapter 14 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Kings Chapter 14.

questions.question: Who fell sick at the time mentioned in 1 Kings Chapter 14?
options: Abijah the son of Jeroboam
Nadab the son of Jeroboam
Rehoboam the son of Solomon
Ahijah the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Abijah the son of Jeroboam
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:1 states that Abijah the son of Jeroboam fell sick at that time.

questions.question: What disguise did Jeroboam's wife take when she went to see the prophet Ahijah?
options: She disguised herself so she would not be known as Jeroboam's wife
She wore royal clothes
She disguised herself as a man
She went openly without disguise
questions.correctAnswer: She disguised herself so she would not be known as Jeroboam's wife
questions.explanation: Jeroboam told his wife to disguise herself so she would not be known as his wife, as per 1 Kings 14:2.

questions.question: What did Jeroboam give his wife to take to the prophet Ahijah?
options: Ten loaves, cracknels, and a cruse of honey
Only bread and water
Some gold and silver
A message from the king of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Ten loaves, cracknels, and a cruse of honey
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:3 notes Jeroboam's wife was to take ten loaves, cracknels, and a cruse of honey to Ahijah.

questions.question: Why could Ahijah not see Jeroboam's wife when she came to his house?
options: Because his eyes were set by reason of his age
Because he was blind from birth
Because it was dark inside
Because she was disguised
questions.correctAnswer: Because his eyes were set by reason of his age
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:4 explains Ahijah could not see because his eyes were set due to his old age.

questions.question: True or False: Ahijah knew the woman was Jeroboam's wife even though she tried to disguise herself.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:6 shows that Ahijah recognized her and said, 'Come in, thou wife of Jeroboam; why feignest thou thyself to be another?'

questions.question: According to 1 Kings 14:7, why did God exalt Jeroboam to be king over Israel?
options: Because God exalted him from among the people and made him prince over Israel
Because Jeroboam was the son of the previous king
Because Jeroboam was a mighty warrior
Because Jeroboam was a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Because God exalted him from among the people and made him prince over Israel
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:7 states God exalted Jeroboam and made him prince over Israel.

questions.question: What did Jeroboam do that was evil according to 1 Kings 14:9?
options: Made other gods and molten images to provoke the LORD to anger
Built the temple in Jerusalem
Followed all the commandments
Destroyed idols in Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Made other gods and molten images to provoke the LORD to anger
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:9 says Jeroboam made other gods and molten images, provoking the LORD to anger.

questions.question: What would happen to Jeroboam's household according to the LORD's message in 1 Kings 14:10?
options: The house of Jeroboam would be cut off and taken away completely
They would prosper and reign forever
They would be made priests
They would be given more land
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Jeroboam would be cut off and taken away completely
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:10 declares that the LORD will bring evil upon Jeroboam's house and take it away as dung is taken away.

questions.question: True or False: Jeroboam's child who was sick would live according to the prophecy.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:12 foretells that when Jeroboam's wife enters the city, the child shall die.

questions.question: Where did Jeroboam's wife return to after visiting Ahijah?
options: Tirzah
Jerusalem
Shiloh
Samaria
questions.correctAnswer: Tirzah
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:17 states that Jeroboam's wife arose and came to Tirzah after the visit.

questions.question: Who began to reign in Judah after Solomon according to 1 Kings 14:21?
options: Rehoboam the son of Solomon
Abijam the son of Rehoboam
Jeroboam the son of Nebat
Ahijah the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Rehoboam the son of Solomon
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:21 reports that Rehoboam, son of Solomon, reigned in Judah after Solomon.

questions.question: What did Judah do in the sight of the LORD during Rehoboam's reign?
options: Judah did evil and provoked the LORD to jealousy
Judah followed all the commandments
Judah destroyed idols
Judah remained faithful
questions.correctAnswer: Judah did evil and provoked the LORD to jealousy
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:22 states that Judah did evil in the sight of the LORD and provoked him to jealousy.

questions.question: True or False: Shishak king of Egypt took treasures from the house of the LORD during Rehoboam's reign.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:26 says Shishak took away the treasures of the house of the LORD and the king's house.

questions.question: What did King Rehoboam make to replace the gold shields taken by Shishak?
options: Brazen shields
Silver shields
Iron shields
No replacements
questions.correctAnswer: Brazen shields
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:27 reveals that Rehoboam made brazen shields to replace the gold shields taken by Shishak.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 1 Kings 14:30: 'And there was war between ______ and Jeroboam all their days.'
options: Rehoboam
Solomon
Ahijah
Shishak
questions.correctAnswer: Rehoboam
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 14:30 states there was war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam all their days.

medium.title: 1 Kings Chapter 14 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Kings Chapter 14 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on 1 Kings 14, what biblical truth about God's justice and mercy would you share?
options: God punishes sin but shows mercy when there is some good found in a person.
God ignores sin and always blesses regardless of behavior.
God only punishes leaders and ignores the people.
God rewards everyone equally regardless of their actions.
questions.correctAnswer: God punishes sin but shows mercy when there is some good found in a person.
questions.explanation: The chapter shows that Jeroboam’s house was judged for sin (verses 10-16), but his sick son was the only one buried because some good was found in him (verses 12-13). This teaches that God's justice is real, yet His mercy can be evident where goodness is found.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 14 teach us about obedience to God's commands through Jeroboam's example?
options: Jeroboam disobeyed God by making other gods and provoking Him to anger.
Jeroboam obeyed God fully and was blessed for it.
Jeroboam was neutral and did not make any religious changes.
Jeroboam strictly followed David’s example.
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam disobeyed God by making other gods and provoking Him to anger.
questions.explanation: Jeroboam is criticized for doing evil more than those before him and making other gods, which provoked God's anger (verses 8-9). This highlights the importance of obedience to God’s commands.

questions.question: If a believer struggles with trusting God's plan during suffering, what can 1 Kings 14 teach about trusting God’s sovereignty and timing?
options: God’s plans unfold in His timing, even if it involves hardship or loss.
God’s plans always avoid hardships for believers.
God’s plans depend on human strength only.
God punishes believers without purpose.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s plans unfold in His timing, even if it involves hardship or loss.
questions.explanation: Jeroboam’s son died exactly as God spoke through Ahijah, showing that God’s sovereignty includes timing of events (verses 12, 17-18). This teaches believers to trust in God’s timing despite difficulties.

questions.question: Based on 1 Kings 14, what biblical principle can guide parents in teaching their children about faithfulness?
options: Faithfulness to God in the family is crucial, and even partial goodness is recognized by God.
Parents should ignore children's spirituality because they will choose their own path.
Children’s behavior does not affect God’s blessings on the family.
Only kings need to follow God’s commands, not families.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to God in the family is crucial, and even partial goodness is recognized by God.
questions.explanation: Jeroboam’s son was the only one buried because some good was found in him toward the Lord (verse 13), highlighting the importance of faithfulness within the family.

questions.question: How does the chapter teach about humility and contentment in leadership based on Jeroboam's reign?
options: Jeroboam failed by not humbling himself and obeying God, leading to judgment.
Jeroboam was humble and content, leading to a peaceful reign.
Jeroboam ignored God but was still successful.
Leaders do not need to obey God to be effective.
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam failed by not humbling himself and obeying God, leading to judgment.
questions.explanation: Jeroboam did evil and was not like David who followed God with all his heart, resulting in God’s judgment (verses 8-10). This teaches leaders to humbly obey God.

questions.question: A believer feels tempted to compromise their integrity at work. What lesson does 1 Kings 14 provide about honesty and integrity?
options: Obedience to God and faithfulness are essential, and compromise leads to consequences.
Integrity is optional if it benefits you.
Honesty is not important for leaders.
God rewards those who find shortcuts.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God and faithfulness are essential, and compromise leads to consequences.
questions.explanation: Jeroboam’s disobedience and idolatry brought destruction on his house (verses 9-10), showing that compromise with sin leads to judgment.

questions.question: How is the importance of prayer and seeking God shown through Jeroboam’s wife’s visit to Ahijah?
options: Seeking God’s guidance is important even in difficult circumstances.
Prayer and seeking God are unnecessary when problems arise.
Only kings should seek God’s prophets.
Disguise and deception are the best way to approach God.
questions.correctAnswer: Seeking God’s guidance is important even in difficult circumstances.
questions.explanation: Jeroboam’s wife was sent to ask the prophet Ahijah about her sick son (verses 2-3), showing the value of seeking God’s direction through His servants.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Kings 14, Jeroboam’s reign was marked by faithfulness to God and peace with Judah.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeroboam did evil and made Israel sin (verses 9, 16), and there was war between him and Rehoboam of Judah (verse 30), showing unfaithfulness and conflict.

questions.question: True or False: The chapter teaches that God’s blessings depend on one’s obedience and avoiding idolatry.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: God warned Jeroboam because of his idolatry and disobedience, leading to judgment (verses 9-10), indicating blessings depend on obedience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeroboam’s wife brought ________, cracknels, and a cruse of honey to Ahijah as a sign of seeking God’s word.
options: ten loaves
five loaves
a jar of oil
a basket of fruit
questions.correctAnswer: ten loaves
questions.explanation: Jeroboam instructed his wife to take ten loaves, cracknels, and honey to Ahijah to inquire about their sick child (verse 3), showing symbolic offering when seeking God.

questions.question: Based on 1 Kings 14, what can believers learn about the consequences of leading others into sin?
options: Leaders causing sin bring judgment not only upon themselves but also upon those they lead.
Leaders are never held accountable for others’ sins.
Sinful leadership has no real consequences on the nation.
Judgment only affects the leader personally.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders causing sin bring judgment not only upon themselves but also upon those they lead.
questions.explanation: The chapter says Israel was given over because of Jeroboam’s sins, who made Israel sin (verse 16), teaching that sinful leadership affects many.

questions.question: How does the chapter highlight the importance of humility in family and leadership roles?
options: Jeroboam failed by not following God wholeheartedly, resulting in destruction of his family line.
Jeroboam’s humility led to peace and prosperity.
Family roles are not important in God’s plan.
Pride in leadership has no consequences.
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam failed by not following God wholeheartedly, resulting in destruction of his family line.
questions.explanation: Jeroboam was rebuked for not being like David who followed God with all his heart (verse 8), leading to the downfall of his house (verses 10-14).

questions.question: What practical teaching about perseverance through trials can be drawn from Jeroboam’s wife’s journey to Ahijah?
options: Even in distress, seeking God's word requires faith and courage.
Avoid seeking God when facing difficulties.
Only kings should ask prophets for guidance.
Disguise and fear are the best approaches to God.
questions.correctAnswer: Even in distress, seeking God's word requires faith and courage.
questions.explanation: Jeroboam’s wife disguised herself and went to the prophet despite the danger, showing the need for faith to seek God’s guidance in trials (verses 2-6).

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 14 instruct believers about generosity and stewardship in spiritual life?
options: True devotion to God requires obedience and faithfulness, not just offerings.
Offering gifts guarantees God’s favor regardless of behavior.
Stewardship is not related to obedience.
Material gifts replace the need for obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: True devotion to God requires obedience and faithfulness, not just offerings.
questions.explanation: Jeroboam’s offerings did not save him because he disobeyed God; God judged him for idolatry (verses 3, 9-10), teaching obedience is key.

questions.question: What does the conflict between Rehoboam and Jeroboam teach about reconciliation and peace in the church and community?
options: Division and ongoing war hinder God’s people and should be avoided.
Conflict is acceptable and encouraged among believers.
Peace is unnecessary in the community of faith.
Leaders should always prioritize power over unity.
questions.correctAnswer: Division and ongoing war hinder God’s people and should be avoided.
questions.explanation: Verse 30 states war existed between Rehoboam and Jeroboam all their days, showing division harms God's people and peace is preferable.

questions.question: How can the account of Rehoboam’s reign encourage humility and gratitude in believers?
options: Despite his faults, God’s chosen city was Jerusalem, reminding believers to be grateful and humble.
Rehoboam was perfect and needed no humility.
Believers do not need gratitude for God’s choices.
Pride ensures God’s blessings.
questions.correctAnswer: Despite his faults, God’s chosen city was Jerusalem, reminding believers to be grateful and humble.
questions.explanation: Rehoboam reigned in Jerusalem, the city God chose (verse 21), but Judah did evil (verse 22), teaching believers to be humble and grateful for God’s blessings despite failures.

hard.title: 1 Kings Chapter 14 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Kings Chapter 14.

questions.question: What disguise was Jeroboam's wife instructed to use when she went to see the prophet Ahijah?
options: To feign herself as another woman
To dress as a prophetess
To carry royal insignia
To wear sackcloth and ashes
questions.correctAnswer: To feign herself as another woman
questions.explanation: Jeroboam told his wife to disguise herself so she would not be known as his wife, and Ahijah said she would feign herself to be another woman (1 Kings 14:2, 5).

questions.question: What items did Jeroboam instruct his wife to take to Ahijah?
options: Ten loaves, cracknels, and a cruse of honey
Wine, oil, and frankincense
A lamb, bread, and water
Gold, silver, and spices
questions.correctAnswer: Ten loaves, cracknels, and a cruse of honey
questions.explanation: Jeroboam instructed his wife to take ten loaves, cracknels, and a cruse of honey to Ahijah as a gift and sign (1 Kings 14:3).

questions.question: Why could Ahijah not see when Jeroboam's wife came to him?
options: Because his eyes were set by reason of his age
Because he was in a dark room
Because he was blind from birth
Because he was wearing a veil
questions.correctAnswer: Because his eyes were set by reason of his age
questions.explanation: The text states that Ahijah could not see because his eyes were set due to his old age (1 Kings 14:4).

questions.question: What is the significance of Ahijah addressing Jeroboam's wife directly despite her disguise?
options: It shows the prophetic insight and divine revelation
It reveals that Ahijah was blind but had spiritual vision
It indicates a literary device of irony
All of the above
questions.correctAnswer: All of the above
questions.explanation: Ahijah's ability to recognize her despite her disguise illustrates divine revelation, spiritual insight beyond physical sight, and serves as an ironic element in the narrative (1 Kings 14:5-6).

questions.question: What reason does the LORD give for bringing evil upon the house of Jeroboam?
options: Jeroboam made other gods and molten images, provoking the LORD to anger
Jeroboam oppressed the poor and widows
Jeroboam refused to build the temple
Jeroboam allied with Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam made other gods and molten images, provoking the LORD to anger
questions.explanation: The LORD condemns Jeroboam for making other gods and molten images, which provoked His anger (1 Kings 14:9-10).

questions.question: How does the judgment on Jeroboam's family foreshadow the concept of divine retribution in later biblical texts?
options: It prefigures the complete removal of unfaithful dynasties as seen in the exile narratives
It shows the mercy of God towards sinners
It emphasizes political alliances over faithfulness
It reflects the cyclical nature of kingship
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures the complete removal of unfaithful dynasties as seen in the exile narratives
questions.explanation: The judgment on Jeroboam's house anticipates total divine retribution and removal of disobedient dynasties, a theme developed in exile accounts (1 Kings 14:10-15).

questions.question: What is the destiny of Jeroboam's son according to Ahijah's prophecy?
options: He will die as soon as his mother returns home
He will reign long and prosper
He will be exiled to Egypt
He will become a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: He will die as soon as his mother returns home
questions.explanation: Ahijah told Jeroboam's wife that her son would die when she entered the city (1 Kings 14:12, 17).

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'he only of Jeroboam shall come to the grave'?
options: It indicates he was the only one in Jeroboam's house who found favor with the LORD
It means he was the only son of Jeroboam
It shows he was the only king from Jeroboam's house
It signifies he was the only one who died naturally
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates he was the only one in Jeroboam's house who found favor with the LORD
questions.explanation: The verse explains that only this son was found to have some good thing toward the LORD in Jeroboam's house (1 Kings 14:13).

questions.question: Which king is prophesied to arise and cut off the house of Jeroboam?
options: A king the LORD shall raise up over Israel
King David's descendant
The king of Egypt
Rehoboam, king of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: A king the LORD shall raise up over Israel
questions.explanation: The LORD will raise up a king over Israel who will cut off Jeroboam's house (1 Kings 14:14).

questions.question: What does the shaking of Israel 'as a reed is shaken in the water' symbolize in the prophecy?
options: Instability and vulnerability of Israel
Prosperity and growth
Divine protection and strength
Permanent settlement in the land
questions.correctAnswer: Instability and vulnerability of Israel
questions.explanation: The simile expresses how Israel will be uprooted and scattered because of their sins, emphasizing their instability (1 Kings 14:15).

questions.question: What sin specifically is attributed to Jeroboam as causing Israel's downfall?
options: Making Israel to sin by his own sin
Idolatry of Baal alone
Neglecting the temple sacrifices
Alliance with Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Making Israel to sin by his own sin
questions.explanation: The LORD gave Israel up because of Jeroboam's sins, who caused Israel to sin (1 Kings 14:16).

questions.question: What historical event involving Shishak king of Egypt is recorded in this chapter?
options: Shishak came against Jerusalem and took away the treasures of the LORD's house and the king's house
Shishak formed an alliance with Rehoboam
Shishak was defeated by Rehoboam
Shishak built a temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Shishak came against Jerusalem and took away the treasures of the LORD's house and the king's house
questions.explanation: In the fifth year of Rehoboam, Shishak attacked Jerusalem and took away treasures including gold shields Solomon had made (1 Kings 14:25-26).

questions.question: How did King Rehoboam respond to the loss of the gold shields taken by Shishak?
options: He made brass shields and assigned them to the chief of the guard
He ceased wearing any shields
He requested more gold from Egypt
He declared war to reclaim the shields
questions.correctAnswer: He made brass shields and assigned them to the chief of the guard
questions.explanation: Rehoboam replaced the gold shields with brass ones and gave them to the guard in charge of the king's house (1 Kings 14:27).

questions.question: True or False: The chapter records that Rehoboam built high places and images, provoking the LORD to jealousy.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chapter states that Judah under Rehoboam did evil, building high places and images, provoking the LORD (1 Kings 14:22-23).

questions.question: What is the significance of the inclusion of Naamah, an Ammonitess, as Rehoboam's mother in the narrative?
options: It highlights the foreign influence and potential religious syncretism in Judah's royal line
It signifies the purity of Rehoboam's lineage
It indicates an alliance with Egypt
It emphasizes Rehoboam's legitimacy as king
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights the foreign influence and potential religious syncretism in Judah's royal line
questions.explanation: Mentioning Naamah, an Ammonitess, suggests foreign influence that may have contributed to Judah's idolatry and sins (1 Kings 14:21, 31).

questions.question: What literary device is present in the prophecy of Jeroboam's downfall and the immediate death of his son?
options: Foreshadowing of divine judgment
Parable
Allegory
Typology of the Davidic covenant
questions.correctAnswer: Foreshadowing of divine judgment
questions.explanation: The prophecy foreshadows the judgment on Jeroboam’s house, showing the immediate consequence of sin (1 Kings 14:10-12, 17).

theological.title: 1 Kings Chapter 14 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Kings Chapter 14 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What reason did Jeroboam give his wife for disguising herself when she was sent to the prophet Ahijah?
options: So she would not be known as Jeroboam's wife
To deceive the king of Judah
To hide her wealth from the people
To attend a religious festival unnoticed
questions.correctAnswer: So she would not be known as Jeroboam's wife
questions.explanation: Jeroboam told his wife to disguise herself so she would not be known as his wife when she went to see the prophet Ahijah (1 Kings 14:2). This illustrates the fear and secrecy surrounding the seeking of prophetic counsel.

questions.question: What items did Jeroboam instruct his wife to take to the prophet Ahijah?
options: Ten loaves, cracknels, and a cruse of honey
Bread, wine, and oil
Figs, dates, and a lamb
Water, flour, and olives
questions.correctAnswer: Ten loaves, cracknels, and a cruse of honey
questions.explanation: Jeroboam instructed his wife to take ten loaves, cracknels, and a cruse of honey to the prophet Ahijah as a token or offering, indicating the seriousness of the request concerning their sick son (1 Kings 14:3). This shows the cultural practice of bringing food when visiting a prophet.

questions.question: Why could Ahijah not see Jeroboam’s wife when she came to his house?
options: Because his eyes were set by reason of his age
Because he was blind from birth
Because he was in a dark room
Because he was overcome by the Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Because his eyes were set by reason of his age
questions.explanation: Ahijah could not see Jeroboam's wife because his eyes were dim due to old age, which highlights that God’s revelations do not depend on natural sight but on divine revelation (1 Kings 14:4). This aligns with other biblical examples where God works through impaired human faculties (e.g., Moses’ staff, Paul's conversion).

questions.question: What message did the LORD give to Ahijah concerning Jeroboam’s household?
options: That evil would come upon the house and Jeroboam's line would be cut off
That Jeroboam would reign peacefully
That the child would be healed
That Jeroboam would conquer his enemies
questions.correctAnswer: That evil would come upon the house and Jeroboam's line would be cut off
questions.explanation: God revealed through Ahijah that because of Jeroboam’s sins, evil would come upon his house and his descendants would be cut off, demonstrating God's judgment against persistent idolatry and disobedience (1 Kings 14:10). This judgment theme is consistent with Deuteronomy 28 and the prophetic calls to repentance.

questions.question: What reason did God give for judging Jeroboam and his house?
options: Jeroboam made other gods and provoked the LORD to anger
Jeroboam was a poor king
Jeroboam failed to build the temple
Jeroboam lost battles to his enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam made other gods and provoked the LORD to anger
questions.explanation: God judged Jeroboam because he made other gods and molten images, provoking God to anger and turning away from His commandments (1 Kings 14:9). This reflects the biblical doctrine of idolatry as the root of sin and judgment (Exodus 20:3-5; Jeremiah 10:10).

questions.question: What specific fate was pronounced for Jeroboam's descendants who died inside the city and in the field?
options: Those who died in the city would be eaten by dogs, and those in the field by birds
They would be buried with honor
They would be taken captive
They would die peacefully in their homes
questions.correctAnswer: Those who died in the city would be eaten by dogs, and those in the field by birds
questions.explanation: God declared that Jeroboam's descendants who died in the city would be eaten by dogs and those who died in the field by birds, signifying disgrace and divine judgment (1 Kings 14:11). This imagery is echoed in Psalms 59:6-14 and Matthew 7:6 as divine judgment and shame.

questions.question: Who was the only one of Jeroboam’s house that would be buried because something good was found in him?
options: The sick child (Abijah)
Nadab, his son
Jeroboam himself
Ahijah the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: The sick child (Abijah)
questions.explanation: The sick child was the only one of Jeroboam's house to be buried because some good was found in him toward the LORD (1 Kings 14:13). This indicates God’s justice and mercy, rewarding even small faithfulness (Hebrews 11:6; Romans 2:6-11).

questions.question: What consequence did the LORD say would come upon Israel because of Jeroboam's sins?
options: Israel would be smitten and scattered beyond the river
Israel would be victorious over all enemies
Israel would be blessed with peace and prosperity
Israel would build a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: Israel would be smitten and scattered beyond the river
questions.explanation: The LORD declared that Israel would be smitten and scattered beyond the river because of Jeroboam's sins, illustrating the corporate consequences of a leader's sin on a nation (1 Kings 14:15). This aligns with Deuteronomy 28:64 and the exile theme in biblical theology.

questions.question: How did Jeroboam's wife react after receiving the prophecy from Ahijah?
options: She arose and departed, and the child died at the threshold
She stayed and prayed for healing
She returned to confront Jeroboam
She went to the temple to offer sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: She arose and departed, and the child died at the threshold
questions.explanation: Jeroboam’s wife left after hearing the prophecy, and the child died as foretold (1 Kings 14:17). This fulfillment underscores the certainty of God's word through prophecy (Isaiah 55:11; Deuteronomy 18:22).

questions.question: What was the general spiritual condition of Judah during Rehoboam’s reign according to this chapter?
options: Judah did evil and provoked the LORD to jealousy with their sins
Judah was faithful and sought the LORD
Judah was neutral and had no major sins
Judah rebuilt the temple and worshiped only Yahweh
questions.correctAnswer: Judah did evil and provoked the LORD to jealousy with their sins
questions.explanation: Judah is described as doing evil and provoking the LORD to jealousy by committing sins worse than their ancestors (1 Kings 14:22). This highlights the biblical theme of covenant unfaithfulness and divine jealousy (Exodus 34:14; Ezekiel 8).

questions.question: What specific sins are mentioned as being practiced in Judah during Rehoboam's reign?
options: Building high places, images, groves, and sodomy
Only idolatry
Worshiping the LORD exclusively
Keeping all the Mosaic laws perfectly
questions.correctAnswer: Building high places, images, groves, and sodomy
questions.explanation: Judah committed several abominations including building high places, images, groves, and sodomy (1 Kings 14:23-24). These sins violated the first and second commandments and led to God’s judgment (Leviticus 18; Deuteronomy 12).

questions.question: Who came against Jerusalem in the fifth year of Rehoboam's reign and what did he take?
options: Shishak king of Egypt; he took the treasures of the LORD's house and the king’s house
Nebuchadnezzar; he destroyed the temple
Assyrians; they took the Ark of the Covenant
Babylonians; they burned Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Shishak king of Egypt; he took the treasures of the LORD's house and the king’s house
questions.explanation: Shishak king of Egypt attacked Jerusalem and took away the treasures from the house of the LORD and the king's house, illustrating the consequences of Judah’s unfaithfulness and God's allowing foreign invasion as judgment (1 Kings 14:25-26). This is consistent with the biblical pattern of judgment (Judges 2:14-15).

questions.question: What did King Rehoboam do in place of the gold shields taken by Shishak?
options: He made brass shields and gave them to the chief of the guard
He made silver shields and placed them in the temple
He did not replace them
He made wooden shields and distributed to the soldiers
questions.correctAnswer: He made brass shields and gave them to the chief of the guard
questions.explanation: Rehoboam replaced the gold shields with brass ones and entrusted them to the chief of the guard, symbolizing diminished glory and divine judgment upon the kingdom (1 Kings 14:27). This reflects the biblical theme of loss due to sin (Isaiah 30:1-3).

questions.question: What does the chapter say about the relationship between Rehoboam and Jeroboam during their reigns?
options: There was war between them all their days
They formed an alliance and ruled peacefully
They never interacted
They exchanged gifts and made treaties
questions.correctAnswer: There was war between them all their days
questions.explanation: The chapter states that war continued between Rehoboam and Jeroboam during their entire reigns (1 Kings 14:30), illustrating the ongoing division and strife within the divided kingdom, a theme consistent with the consequences of Israel's disobedience (Psalm 2).

questions.question: What is recorded about the end of Rehoboam’s life and succession?
options: He died and was buried in the city of David, and Abijam his son reigned in his place
He died in battle and had no successor
He abdicated the throne to Jeroboam
He was taken captive and exiled
questions.correctAnswer: He died and was buried in the city of David, and Abijam his son reigned in his place
questions.explanation: Rehoboam died and was buried with his ancestors in the city of David, and his son Abijam succeeded him (1 Kings 14:31). This continuation of David’s dynasty reflects God's covenant promises despite the nation’s failures (2 Samuel 7).
